questions.text: In a patient with h/o stroke, on MR angiography, there is occlusion of the right vertebral artery. All of the following are possible for this patient except:

options.label: B
options.text: Left-sided loss of temperature and pain

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left-sided cerebellar ataxia Here, the patient has an occlusion of the right vertebral artery. Thus, this is a case of right Wallenberg syndrome, which shows I/L ataxia. (Right side)

Highyeild:

Lateral medullary/Wallenberg/PICA syndrome- Spinothalamic tract: C/L loss of pain and temperature Spinocerebellar reactions: I/L ataxia Sympathetic -I/L Horner’s syndrome Sensory tract of V nerve- I/L loss of face sensation Vestibular nucleus: Vertigo, Nausea, and vomiting Nucleus ambiguus- Dysphagia, Dysarthria Vertebral Artery > PICA PICA- Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,B,D are seen in this patient.

Extraedge:

Medullary Syndrome Q. Most common vessel affected Lateral and medial Vertebral artery Lateral/Wallenberg /PICA Vertebral Artery >PICA PICA- Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery Medial Vertebral artery >Anterior spinal artery

questions.text: In a patient with h/o stroke, on MR angiography there is infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery. All of the following features are seen in the patient except:

options.label: D
options.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature

questions.correct_answer: D. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contralateral loss of pain and temperature There is an infarction of the paramedian branches of anterior spinal artery. This is a case of medial medullary syndrome, as the spinothalamic tract is not involved here . Therefore , Pain and temperature is spared.

Highyeild:

Medial medullary syndrome- Medial lemniscus-C/L loss of proprioception Medial longitudinal fasciculus-INO (InterNuclear ophthalmoplegia) Motor pathways-C/L weakness Vertebral artery> Anterior spinal artery I/L 12th nerve palsy- tongue atrophy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,B,C are seen in Medial medullary syndrome

Extraedge:

Medullary Syndrome Q. Most common vessel affected Lateral and medial Vertebral artery Lateral/Wallenberg /PICA Vertebral Artery >PICA PICA- Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery Medial Vertebral artery >Anterior spinal artery

questions.text: In a patient with damage to the right ventromedial brainstem, which is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery. All of the following features are possible in this patient except:

options.label: A
options.text: The right-sided eye is down and out

options.label: B
options.text: Paralysis of left-sided muscles of mastication

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right-sided facial palsy In the patient, there is a right ventromedial brainstem injury, which is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery. This is a case of right-sided weber syndrome which will have C/L, that is left-side facial nerve palsy.

Highyeild:

Weber’s syndrome- Cerebral peduncle lesion Posterior cerebral artery infarct 3rd nerve palsy-I/L ophthalmoplegia-down and out eye Motor tracts-C/L weakness Substantia nigra-C/L parkinsonism Corticobulbar tract-C/L UMN 7th nerve palsy C/L 12th nerve palsy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,B,C are seen in Weber’s syndrome .

questions.text: In a patient there is an occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. All of the following are involved in this condition except:

options.label: C
options.text: Spinal sensory nucleus of 5th cranial nerve

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypoglossal Nerve Nuclei There is an occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery in this patient. This leads to the development of lateral medullary syndrome. Hypoglossal nerve nuclei are present in the midline. This is not affected by lateral medullary syndrome .

Highyeild:

Lateral medullary/Wallenberg/PICA syndrome- Spinothalamic tract-C/L loss of pain and temperature Spinocerebellar reacts- I/L ataxia Sympathetic -I/L Horner’s syndrome Sensory tract of V nerve- I/L loss of face sensation Vestibular nucleus- Vertigo,Nausea and vomiting Nucleus ambiguus- Dysphagia, Dysarthria Nucleus tractus solitarius -I/L loss of taste Vertebral Artery >PICA PICA- Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery. Medial medullary syndrome- Medial lemniscus-C/L loss of proprioception Medial longitudinal fasciculus-INO(InterNuclear ophthalmoplegia) Motor pathways-C/L weakness Vertebral artery>Anterior spinal artery I/L 12th nerve palsy-Tongue atrophy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C, D are seen in lateral medullary syndrome

Extraedge:

Medullary Syndrome Q. Most common vessel affected Lateral and medial Vertebral artery Lateral/Wallenberg /PICA Vertebral Artery >PICA PICA- Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery Medial Vertebral artery >Anterior spinal artery

questions.text: In the following Image, the shaded pink region with posterior extension is affected. Which of the following will be seen in the patient.

options.label: A
options.text: Ipsilateral paralysis loss of muscles of mastication

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired ipsilateral sensation over one side of face

options.label: D
options.text: Contralateral impaired pain and thermal sense

questions.correct_answer: B. Contralateral impaired touch and proprioception
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contralateral impaired touch and proprioception Pink area involvement suggests Medial mid-pontine syndrome . C/L Touch and proprioception is carried by Medial lemniscus, which is involved in Medial Mid pontine syndrome . Also, all the other options are seen in Lateral brainstem involvement only.

Highyeild:

. Medial mid pontine syndrome (paramedian branch of midbasilar artery) - On side of lesion - Ataxia of limbs and gait (more prominent in bilateral involvement): Pontine nuclei On side opposite lesion- Paralysis of face, arm, and leg : Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract Variable impaired touch and proprioception when lesion extends posteriorly : Medial lemniscus Lateral mid pontine syndrome (short circumferential artery) - On side of lesion- Ataxia of limbs: Middle cerebellar peduncle Paralysis of muscles of mastication : Motor fibers or nucleus of fifth nerve Impaired sensation over side of face: Sensory fibers or nucleus of fifth nerve On side opposite lesion- Impaired pain and thermal sense on limbs and trunk: Spinothalamic tract.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,C,D are seen in Lateral mid-Pontine syndrome.

questions.text: Based on the following Image, the physician wants to differentiate lateral midbrain syndrome from the medial midbrain syndrome. Which of the following is the appropriate answer?

options.label: A
options.text: Ipsilateral eye is down and out in lateral midbrain syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Ipsilateral pupil is dilated and unresponsive in lateral midbrain syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior cerebral artery is involved in lateral midbrain syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Contralateral hemiataxia is seen in lateral midbrain syndrome

questions.correct_answer: D. Contralateral hemiataxia is seen in lateral midbrain syndrome
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contralateral hemiataxia is seen in lateral midbrain syndrome The physician wants to differentiate lateral midbrain syndrome from medial midbrain syndrome ; only one is unique to lateral midbrain syndrome. - Contralateral hemiataxia This is also hyperkinesis and tremor due to the involvement of red nucleus and dentatorubrothalamic pathway This is not seen in medial midbrain syndrome.

Highyeild:

Medial midbrain syndrome (paramedian branches of upper basilar and proximal posterior cerebral arteries)- On side of lesion - Eye “down and out” -secondary to unopposed action of fourth and sixth cranial nerves, with dilated and unresponsive pupils (Third nerve fibers affected). On side opposite lesion - Paralysis of face, arm, and leg : Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract descending in crus cerebri. Lateral midbrain syndrome (syndrome of small penetrating arteries arising from posterior cerebral artery) - On side of lesion - Eye “down and out”- secondary to unopposed action of fourth and sixth cranial nerves, with dilated and unresponsive pupil ( Third nerve fibers and/or third nerve nucleus affected) On side opposite lesion - Hemiataxia, hyperkinesia, tremor : Red nucleus , dentatorubrothalamic pathway

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options :- Option A,B,C are seen in both medial and lateral midbrain syndrome.

questions.text: The patient is brought to the scene in an unconscious state following RTA. A physical examination reveals right-dilated pupils. The patient is likely to develop following features in due course of time, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Convergent Squint Convergent squint: Convergent squint is caused by 6th nerve palsy . The patient is presenting with a dilated pupil following RTA . If parasympathetic supply to the right eye is affected, means 3rd cranial nerve is involved. ( Uncal Herniation ) Sequential compression of the I/L 3rd nerve , the C/L brainstem , the whole brainstem

Highyeild:

Uncal transtentorial herniation refers to impaction of the anterior medial temporal gyrus (the uncus) into the tentorial opening just anterior to and adjacent to the midbrain . Features of Uncal transtentorial herniation are- Early - I/L dilated pupils Later - I/L Hemiplegia (Option A) 3rd nerve palsy Ptosis & divergent squint ( Option C ) Cheyne-Stokes breathing Still later - Quadriplegia ( Option B ) Fixed dilated pupils Erratic respiration Death

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A,B,C are seen in Uncal herniation .

Extraedge:

Kernohan-Woltman sign- Misleading Contralateral dilated pupil and ipsilateral hemiparesis due to contralateral compression of the Kernohan notch.

questions.text: The patient is brought to the casualty following RTA in an unconscious state. Physical examination reveals irregular respiration, a small, reacting pupil, and B/L extensor plantars. He can develop all of the following except:
questions.correct_answer: D. Fixed and non dilated pupils
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fixed and non dilated pupils This is a case of central herniation as the patient is presenting with a small, reacting pupil.

Highyeild:

Central or Downward transtentorial herniation- The halamus and structures which lie between upper brainstem and cerebral hemisphere herniates from the supratentorial to the infratentorial compartment through the tentorial opening . There occurs sequential compression of upper midbrain, pons, medulla. Early features Erratic respiration Small reacting pupil Increased limb tone B/L extensor plantars Late features- Cheyne-Stokes respiration Decorticate rigidity Still later- Fixed dilated pupils Decerebrate rigidity

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, C can be seen in Central /Downward transtentorial herniation.

questions.text: The patient is brought to the casualty following RTA in an unconscious state. Imaging reveals an uncal herniation. Unconsciousness in this case can mainly be attributed to:

options.label: B
options.text: Damage to the Reticular Activating System

questions.correct_answer: B. Damage to the Reticular Activating System
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Damage to the Reticular Activating System In uncal herniation main reason for unconsciousness is damage to RAS( Reticular Activating System )

Highyeild:

Uncal herniation- Uncal transtentorial herniation refers to impaction of the anterior medial temporal gyrus (the uncus ) into the tentorial opening just anterior to and adjacent to the midbrain. The uncus can compress the third nerve as the nerve traverses the subarachnoid space, causing enlargement of the ipsilateral pupil as the first sign (the fibers subserving p arasympathetic pupillary function are located p eripherally in the nerve). The coma that typically follows is due to lateral displacement of the midbrain (and therefore the RAS ) against the opposite tentorial edge by the displaced parahippocampal gyrus . Also compressing the opposite cerebral peduncle and producing a Babinski sign and ipsilateral hemiparesis (the Kernohan-Woltman sign ). Herniation may also compress the anterior and posterior cerebral arteries as they pass over the tentorial reflections, with resultant brain infarction. These distortions may also entrap portions of the ventricular system, causing hydrocephalus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Though A, B, and C can lead to unconsciousness , in uncal herniation the main reason is damage to RAS ( reticular activating system )

Extraedge:

Kernohan-Woltman sign- Misleading Contralateral dilated pupil and ipsilateral hemiparesis due to contralateral compression of the Kernohan notch.

questions.text: The patient with space occupying lesions in temporal and occipital lobe. Which of the following can occur as a complication?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trans tentorial herniation Space-occupying lesions in the temporal lobe are likely to cause herniation of the temporal lobe . Hence, the answer is uncal or trans tentorial herniation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. cerebellar herniation or foraminal herniation: downward forcing of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum. Option: C. Cingulate herniation, and Option D: Transfalcial herniation (displacement of the cingulate gyrus under the falx and across the midline).

questions.text: A head injured patient, who opens eyes to painful stimuli, is confused and localizes to pain. What is the Glasgow coma score:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

11 Glasgow coma score- E- Open eyes to pain -2 V -Confused - 4 M -Localizes to pain - 5 Total score=11 Options A, B, D are incorrect.

Highyeild:

The Glasgow Coma Scale (CGS) provides a practical indicator of gross neurologic status by assessing motor function, verbal responses, and the patient’s ability to open his or her eyes voluntarily or in response to external commands and stimuli. The grading is applied to the best response that can be elicited from the patient at the time of assessment, preferably before any paralyzing or sedating medication is administered or the patient is intubated , as these interventions confound interpretation of the score. The GCS assessment produces scores ranging from 3 to 15. EYE OPENING (E) VERBAL RESPONSE (V) EYE OPENING (E) Oriented 5 Spontaneous 4 Confused 4 To speech 3 Words 3 To pressure 2 Sounds 2 None 1 None 1 Best Motor Response (M Obeying commands 6 Localizing 5 Normal flexion 4 Abnormal flexion 3 Extension 2 None 1

Extraedge:

GCS Brain injury 13-15 Mild 9-12 Moderate 3-8 Severe
